title: The Best Coding Shortcuts For Beginners
summary: Don’t become drowned in details when programming, and if you are a beginner, you will likely become lost in the details. As a beginner coder, it’s best to start with a simple language such as HTML or Python. You can master the art of coding by learning as many shortcuts as you can. If you learn shortcuts, you’ll be able to type faster and more accurately, and you'll save a lot of time and energy in the process. Go Pro With Vim Shortcuts, you should learn a few Vim shortcuts.

Everything is new, nothing makes sense and you can\u2019t even tell if you are on the right track or not. It feels like one confusing labyrinth with a lot of locked doors \u2013 every time you find an unlocked door, it just leads to another locked door! How do we get out of this frustrating loop? Coding shortcuts!
A lot of coders will tell you that in order to be a successful coder, you need to know everything about coding and all its ins and outs. However, there is a reason why even experienced programmers take note of coding shortcuts. These little tricks make life easier for anyone who is just getting started with coding and doesn\u2019t have time to invest in learning every last bit of it before they can start creating useful programs.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

This is especially true if you try to learn every programming language or development environment as if you were studying for a degree.
During your learning process, you\u2019ll probably discover that even simple tasks are far more complex than you imagined. You\u2019ll find that writing code can be a lot like solving a puzzle; you have to have the right pieces, put them in the right order, and use them in the right way to get the desired results.
However, when you try to learn everything all at once, you\u2019ll quickly become overwhelmed by the sheer mass of information. You will find it difficult to see the forest for the trees, and you won\u2019t know where to start.`),mdx("h2",null,"Master The Basics"),mdx("p",null,`While it\u2019s important to familiarize yourself with all of the different pieces and parts of programming, before you dive in and try to build a program from scratch, you should take the time to master the basics.
As a beginner coder, it\u2019s best to start with a simple language such as HTML or Python. You can also use a visual integrated development environment (IDE) such as scratch, which is designed for people just learning to code, so that you can focus on the basics without getting lost in the details.
Once you\u2019ve mastered the basics, you\u2019ll be in a position to explore other languages and development environments. Until then, trying to do too much too soon will only lead to frustration.`),mdx("h2",null,"Mastering Typing Shortcuts"),mdx("p",null,`When you\u2019re coding, you\u2019ll come across all sorts of shortcuts. These are special sequences of keystrokes that let you execute a command using less typing. You can master the art of coding by learning as many shortcuts as you can. You\u2019ll be able to type faster and more accurately, and you\u2019ll save a lot of time and energy in the process.
You might think that not knowing shortcuts will not affect your coding ability, but you\u2019d be surprised. If you are not using shortcuts, you\u2019ll spend time going back and retyping parts of your code that you missed the first time around. If you learn shortcuts, you\u2019ll be able to type faster, which means you\u2019ll be able to test your program more quickly. You\u2019ll also be able to catch any mistakes you make more quickly, which is an important thing to keep in mind as a beginner coder.`),mdx("h2",null,"Use an Integrated Development Environment"),mdx("p",null,`If you plan to spend much time coding, you should choose an integrated development environment (IDE) that best fits your needs. An IDE is basically a program that helps you write code, design programs, and test your code.
An IDE can make the entire process of coding easier by providing you with a built-in code editor, debugging tools, visualizations, and more.
You\u2019ll want to choose an IDE that lets you program in the language you are studying, has an extensive code library, and offers various visualizations and debugging tools.
If you can, test out different IDEs with a simple program to make sure it\u2019s ideal for you before you spend lots of time coding.`),mdx("h2",null,"Go Pro With Vim Shortcuts"),mdx("p",null,`If you want to go pro with your coding, you should learn a few Vim shortcuts. Vim is a code editor that lots of programmers use, and Vim shortcuts can really speed up your workflow and help you write code more efficiently.
Vim has a seemingly endless list of shortcuts, and it can be hard to navigate through them all. That\u2019s why you should check out the Vi Cheat Sheet.
If you\u2019re just getting started, it\u2019s best to only focus on a few of the most common and helpful shortcuts. Once you\u2019re comfortable with those, you can explore some of the others.
For example, if you\u2019re coding in Python, you can use a shortcut to run your program, search for a specific piece of code, or write a piece of code, among other things.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,`The road to becoming a successful coder is long, and the path isn\u2019t always straightforward. However, if you are dedicated to your craft, you\u2019ll make progress. With that in mind, you should keep in mind the most important tips for beginners: don\u2019t become drowned in details, master the basics, master typing shortcuts, and use an IDE.
Once you\u2019ve mastered these tips and tricks, you\u2019ll be well on your way to becoming a pro coder.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Learning Python can help you land that dream job. The demand for Python programmers has grown tremendously in recent years, and this trend shows no sign of abating. A recent study by analytics firm Oplesky found that demand for Python developers rose by nearly 50 percent between 2016 and 2017. That\u2019s why learning how to code in Python is so important right now. This beginner's guide will teach you everything you need to know about this versatile programming language, including basic syntax, data types, operators, variables, strings, lists and dictionaries, functions, modules and objects. Whether you\u2019re using the internet to browse websites, stream videos on YouTube or Instagram, upload images to Facebook, or store your favorite songs on Spotify, you\u2019re almost guaranteed to come across data at some point. With so much information floating around online these days, it\u2019s no surprise that programming languages have become so essential in the tech industry. Python is a programming language that makes it easy for anyone to do this type of analytical work. It also excels at processing data faster than any other language. Because of these reasons, scientists are using Python more and more in their work. In fact, Python has become the most popular programming language used by scientists today.
A scientific computing software package called \u201COrange\u201D inspired the creation of Python because its creator wanted to make something easier to use. Other programming languages like MATLAB were not user-friendly enough for general-purpose scientific computing so Guido van Rossum created his own version of it. He named it \u201CPython\u201D after the British comedy group Monty Python \u2013 he was a fan -- and published it as an open source project in 1991 with the New York University AI Lab as its first users.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Unfortunately, there are so many coding languages out there that it can be difficult to know where to start. Luckily, we\u2019re here to help!
